awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Earth System Science at Colorado State University
awd_abstract_narration:
Fifty undergraduate students (10 per year for five years) will be recruited to participate in a 10-week summer residential research experience in Atmospheric Science Department at Colorado State University. The vision is that graduate students in Earth System Science will reflect the diversity of life experiences and demographic characteristics of the US population. The intended impact of this REU-site is to recruit a talented and diverse pool of undergraduate students into graduate study in Earth System Science through the following objectives: (1) to provide a diverse cohort of undergraduate students the opportunity for discovery-based exploration of Earth System Science; (2) to give interns a feel of the graduate school experience; (3) to provide training in effective communication for cross-disciplinary studies, including those that apply data science methods to the Earth Sciences; and (4) to introduce students to the concept of implicit bias, its effects, and counter-measures to promote a more vibrant and productive scientific community.

REU participants will experience the full research process:  choosing a topic; developing a research idea; conducting a literature review; building and using computer skills for research and presentation; leading their own research project (with guidance); learning and applying a variety of research methods to conduct quality research; learning about additional research methods through peer presentations, scientific lectures, and workshops; and presenting their research in written and oral formats to both the CSU Atmospheric Science community and to the broader scientific community. By the conclusion of the summer research program participants will be well-prepared to conduct scientific research and have a deeper understanding of the graduate school experience. Through the REU Site, students will establish a network of peers and mentors who will play an important role in the development of future Earth system scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site in Earth System Science at Colorado State University aimed to diversify the next generation of Earth scientists by providing hands-on research opportunities to undergraduate students from across the United States. Over the course of this project, we successfully recruited and trained 37 talented students, many of whom came from diverse backgrounds in science. This REU program provided undergraduates with the chance to engage in cutting-edge research in Earth System Science. Students worked closely with faculty, research staff, and graduate student mentors to explore a wide range of topics, from climate change impacts to air quality, and severe weather events. They learned valuable research skills, including data analysis, coding, and scientific communication, which are essential for success in graduate school and beyond. Many students presented their findings at national scientific conferences like the American Geophysical Union (AGU) and the American Meteorological Society (AMS), where some received awards for their outstanding work. These experiences not only deepened their understanding of Earth System Science but also honed their ability to think critically and solve complex problems. Many of our REU alumni have gone on to graduate school and diverse careers in the earth system sciences, further developing themselves as next-generation of scientists. The program also focused on increasing diversity in the field, actively recruiting students from various backgrounds and life experiences. We provided training on implicit bias and its effects, fostering a more inclusive and equitable scientific community. Furthermore, the REU program offered professional development opportunities for graduate students and postdocs, who gained valuable mentoring experience.

Beyond academia, the project helped students learn how to communicate their science to the public. They gained skills in explaining complex scientific concepts in understandable ways, which is crucial for increasing public awareness and understanding of important environmental issues. By engaging in research and sharing their findings, these students contributed to a broader understanding of Earth System Science and its relevance to society. The program not only advanced their scientific knowledge and skills but also encouraged them to pursue careers in science and fostered a more diverse and inclusive scientific community.The impacts of this project will extend far into the future as these students become the next generation of leaders in Earth System Science.

In summary, the REU Site in Earth System Science successfully provided undergraduate students with valuable research experience, mentoring, and professional development. The program not only advanced their scientific knowledge and skills but also encouraged them to pursue careers in science and fostered a more diverse and inclusive scientific community.
